solution.text:
Given quadratic equation is : \(x^2 + _{{k-l}}_x - _{{l*k}}_ = 0\)
Let us first split the middle term _{{k-l}}_x as _{k}_x and -_{l}_x
[because \((_{k}_x) \times (-_{l}_x) = -_{{k*l}}_x^2 = (x^2) \times (-_{{k*l}}_)\)]
So,
\(x^2 + _{{k-l}}_x - _{{l*k}}_ = 0\)
\(x^2 + _{k}_x - _{l}_x - _{{l*k}}_ = 0\)
\(x(x + _{k}_)- _{l}_(x + _{k}_) = 0\)
\((x + _{k}_)(x - _{l}_) = 0\)
Now,
\(x^2 + _{{k-l}}_x - _{{l*k}}_ = 0\) can be written as (x + _{k}_)(x - _{l}_) = 0.
So, the value of x for which (x + _{k}_)(x - _{l}_) = 0,
i.e., either x + _{k}_ = 0 or x - _{l}_ = 0.
Now,
x + _{k}_ = 0 gives x = -_{k}_ and x - _{l}_ = 0 gives x = _{l}_
So, x = -_{k}_ and x = _{l}_ are the roots of given quadratic equation.
